fpdescription: Paris, BnF, lat. 16598, f. 37r: Porphyrian Tree. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b9076885z

Paris, BnF, lat. 16611, f. 14v: ‘ [erased], Celarent, Darii, Ferio, Baralipton, Celantes’ Here these names do double-duty; they remind the reader of the mnemonic verse, but they also indicate where the description of each mood can be found in the text. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b90768515
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v: Here you can see how a little ‘Porphyrian tree’ has been added in the inner margin even when there was hardly space. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v:Here you can see how a later reader added large ‘NOTA’ signs as tiemarks, to clear up the puzzle of where to place the gloss. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v:Here you can see how a first reader went really fancyfull with inventing a new tiemark, and how a later reader drew a line between text and gloss to mark them off a bit more clearly. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail), Affirmative and negative propositions: In this example, the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’, is placed at the top left of the square. It’s placed alongside the other universal, but negative, proposition: ‘no men are just.’ At the bottom of the square we find the particular affirmative and particular negative propositions: ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1617684

Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail), Contradictory Relationships: The diagonal lines crossing the centre of the diagram (labelled ‘contradictoriae’) connect propositions which are contradictory to each other. For example, if ‘all men are just’ (the universal affirmative proposition) then ‘some men are not just’ (the particular negative proposition) is a contradictory statement. If ‘all men are just’ then the statement ‘some men are not just’ cannot be true. Similarly, reading across the other diagonal, if ‘no men are just’ then the proposition ‘some men are just’ cannot be true. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1617684

Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail), Contrary Relationships: The placement of the universal affirmative and negative propositions at the top of the square and the particular affirmative and negative propositions at the bottom is also meaningful; these are described as being ‘contrary’ to each other. That is, it is not possible for both of the universal propositions – ‘all men are just’ and ‘all men are not just’ – to be true, although they could be both false. However, while it is possible for both particular propositions – ‘some men are just’ and ‘some men are not just’ – to be true, they cannot both be false. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1617684

Leiden, UB, BPL 25, f. 12r (detail), Subaltern Relationships: Finally, reading alongside the sides of the square, a further relationship between the propositions, that of subalternation, is identified. If the universal affirmative proposition, ‘all men are just’ (placed at the top of the square), is true, then the corresponding particular affirmative proposition, ‘some men are just’ (placed at the bottom of the square), must also be true. Similarly, if the universal negative proposition, ‘no man is just’, is true, then the particular negative proposition, ‘some man is not just’, must also be true. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1617684
Leiden, UB, BPL 88, f. 2r: Square of opposition. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2028417

Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v (detail): In the second set of schemes lines connect terms of the propositions and conclusion in order to indicate how the argument is constructed. Visualising the argument in this way helps understand why it is valid. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282

Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v (detail):: For example, using a ‘mixed’ syllogism: ‘Whether the knowledge of discussing is useful. If good discussion is useful, the science of discussing well is useful. But good discussion is useful... Therefore dialectic is useful.’ http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282

Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v (detail): The scheme is evidence of a reader trying to understand the steps made by Dialectic in reaching this conclusion; the scheme illustrates the reader’s thought process! http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282
Paris, BnF, lat. 7709, f. 52r: Scheme with Substantia, Corpus, Animatum Corpus, Animal, Homo, Socrates. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10548475p

Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 4v: A close up shows how equisite and detailed the penwork is. The size of the initial signifies the structure of the text: the larger the initial, the more important the unit of text is it opens. Red and blue are the usual colours of ink to use for these initials and the penwork, often in alternation. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525

Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 4v: In the red triangle we read: “in voce earum quae sunt”. This is a correction for a passage in the main text, which originally read “que sunt in voce”. In the main tekst, the passage is marked with dots under the letters, signifying that these words should be deleted and replaced by the correction in het margin. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 89v: The scheme begins with two examples of simple propositions which do not ‘convert’: ‘Plato is a philosopher’ ‘Virtue is good’ These syllogisms cannot be converted by simply swopping the subject and predicate terms. ‘A philosopher’ is not necessarily Plato! Similarly, virtue is not the only ‘good’. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 89v: Here the scheme represents Boethius’ account of ‘conversion by opposition’ (‘contraposition’) The second set of propositions: ‘Omnis non homo animal est. Omne animal non homo est.’ (’All non-man is an animal; all animals are not man’) shows how switching the order of the subject and predicate of the sentence generates a new proposition. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 90v: Ch(arles): How many species are there in dialectic? A(lcuin): The most important are 5: ‘isagogae’, categories, syllogistic formulas and definitions, ‘topica’, and ‘perermeniae’. Ch: What are ‘isagogae’? A: Isagoge is the (Greek) word for Latin ‘introductio’, ‘introduction’. Ch: What does ‘introduction’ mean? A: Introduction is … . http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 90v: Ch: What is ‘genus’? A: ‘Genus’ is what can be divided into species: it describes whatever you are investigating in an inclusive word, such as ‘animal’. For each individual species - man, horse, ox, lion etc. – ‘animal’ is the genus and is applied to them all. Ch: What is ‘species’? A: ‘Species’ is …. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 2r: Written nota signs from the original annotating hand (below) and from the later one (above). http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 17v: A foot (?) and a hand at the edge of fol. 17v. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 37r: A hand, leg or arm (?) and face on fol. 37r. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 49v: A head and peculiar animal on fol. 49v. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 18r: In manuscripts, marginal notes are used to (1) call attention to certain things. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 20v: Edge of the page. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 7r: Edge of the page. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986

Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 58r: You can see that the material was already damaged when the scribe was copying the commentary into the margins: he/she deals with the damages parchment and the hole in it. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 25v: ‘Heiricus magister Remigii fecit has glossas’. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 4v. A later reader added a Nota sign, marking a passage as noteworthy. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525

Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 4v. In the bottom margin we find a kind of diagram that often appears in these logical texts: the start of a sentence is broken up in two possible continuations, one of which is again broken up in a set of possible continuations. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525
Paris, BnF, lat. 17806, f. 117r: portrait of a master teaching a student. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b525053525
Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315(605), p.6: The text has been carefully corrected, here ‘ad’ has been corrected to ‘ab’ and ‘actenus’ to ‘hactenus’. http://www.e-codices.ch/en/sbe/0315

Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315(605), p. 6: Here small squiggles have been added in the margin alongside the text; these are rudimentary quotation marks indicating original text from the Isagoge, the subject of Boethius’ commentary. http://www.e-codices.ch/en/sbe/0315

Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 315(605), p. 6: Here interlinear glosses have been added to provide Latin equivalents of the Greek terms hyperbaton (transposition of words) and zeuma (where one word can be used in two different contexts). The glossator describes these as ‘confusus ordo’, the confusion of order, and ‘repetitio’, repetition, respectively. http://www.e-codices.ch/en/sbe/0315

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 103v: A medieval reader has added a content list at the end of the volume, starting with ‘libri boetius’, books of Boethius, and listing the titles. These match the existing contents of BPL 84, so we know that this collection of texts has been together since at least the time it was in this reader’s hands. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 90v: Ch: What is ‘genus’? A: ‘Genus’ is what can be divided into species: it describes whatever you are investigating in an inclusive word, such as ‘animal’. For each individual species - man, horse, ox, lion etc. – ‘animal’ is the genus and is applied to them all. Ch: What is ‘species’? A: ‘Species’ is …. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 32v: An example of numbers (‘ii’), from f. 32v. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775

folioid: You can see that the material was already damaged when the scribe was copying the commentary into the margins: he/she deals with the damages parchment and the hole in it. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986
fpdescription: Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 8v: here we find the quire signature ‘c’, suggesting that this gathering of leaves was once the third in a collection. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 13r: ‘Retro in libro topicorum iii’: ‘Back in book III of the Topics’. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 14r: ‘Retro in fine libri tercium topicorum ciceronis’: ‘Back in the end of the third book of Cicero’s Topics’. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Leiden, UB, BPL 84, f. 44v: two sets of rubrics (written in red) indicate that one text has ended and that another will begin on the next page. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2348775
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f. 27r: Introductions to the author. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10546779x
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f. 27r: Author's portrait. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10546779x
Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f. 27r: Opening of the commentary. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10546779x

Paris, BnF, lat. 7900A, f. 127v: A personification of the discipline of grammar (Lady Grammar) is teaching a schoolclass. The pupils in the front row have wax tablets to practice their letters and words. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10546779x

Leiden, UB, BPL 88, f. 4v: Text in the box, drawn by us: ‘According to Calcidius, entelechy is perfecta aetas, completed lifetime. According to Aristotle, it is interpreted as absolute perfection. Plato, on the other hand, says that entelechy is the anima mundi, the soul of the world.’ http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2028417
Paris, BnF, lat. 12963, f. 8v (detail). Cassiodorus, Institutiones. Ms. from Corbie, second half of the 10th century. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b105442152
Paris, BnF, lat. 16598, f. 37r: Note the distinction made between mortal (and rational) man and mortal (and irrational) cows, dogs, etc. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b9076885z

Paris, BnF, lat. 16598, f. 37r: Here, as might befit a book belonging to a theologian, Peter and Paul substitute for Plato and Socrates as examples of the species ‘man’. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b9076885z

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 24v: At the top of the scheme we find ‘Usia’ , meaning substance, a Latinised form of the Greek οὐσία. Cicero is given as the example of ‘man’. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v: The other scribe added a note on musical pitches, and two sets of schemes regarding syllogistic propositions. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v: A line separates the sets of examples of syllogisms. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282
Leiden, UB, VLF 48, f. 95v: We know who one of these scribes was – Rather of Verona (890-974) added a copy of a letter at the base of the page. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1618282
Leiden, UB, BPL 144, f. 2r. A written Nota sign in the original hand, and a drawn head as attention sign in the later hand. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2356986
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 13v: Here the glossator introduces the characters in the conversation. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 13v: ‘Ecce’, ‘Look’, the glossator writes – ‘an example of induction’ . http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 13v: The glossator indicates who is speaking between the lines (‘Aspasia’s words’, ’Xenophon’s wife responds’ etc). These names and characters may have been unfamiliar to the reader, so these cues helped them follow the text. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135

Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 11r: These schemata summarise Cicero’s discussion of the aspects of human nature (De inventione, I.XXIV.35) which are used to describe people involved in a case. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135
Leiden, UB, GRO 22, f. 58v: a glossator adds Augustine’s list of the eight categories of lies (De mendacio, 25). http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:1668135

Einsiedeln, Stiftsbibliothek, Codex 29 (878), p. 166: This passage of annotation gives us a clue about the kind of readers Cod. 29 (878) was expected to receive. As the first word, ‘ordo’, suggests, this gloss amounts to a reordering of the first words of Porphyry’s text (‘Cum sit necessarium...’). Glosses of this type helped medieval students make sense of Latin, and suggest that this copy of the Isagoge was prepared for an elementary readership. https://www.e-codices.unifr.ch/en/list/one/sbe/0029

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 12r: Introduction (accessus) to the author, Augustine, and an etymology of the word dialectica, with a reference to John Scot Eriugenia. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v

Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 12r: Opening of De dialectica, with the well-known opening words: “Dialectia est bene disputandi scientia”; “Dialectic is the art of arguing well. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 25v: ‘Heiricus magister Remigii fecit has glossas’. https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v
Paris, BnF, lat. 12949, f. 52v: ‘We should not accept this gloss’ - ‘Non est haec glossa a nobis recipienda.’ https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/btv1b10542356v
Leiden, UB, BPL 88, f. 2v: Ninth-century script. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2028417
Leiden, UB, BPL 88, f. 2v: Eleventh-centruy additions. http://hdl.handle.net/1887.1/item:2028417
St. Gallen, SB, Cod. Sang. 128, p. 3: The passage about Marcella. https://www.e-codices.unifr.ch/en/list/one/csg/0128
